Method Detail

getJobCount

public long getJobCount()

setNumberOfWorkers

public void setNumberOfWorkers(int numberOfWorkers)
The main thread in the master process invokes this method to tell the job manager how many workers participate in the distributed algorithm.
The number is based on the number of participating nodes (machines), multiplied by the number of worker threads per node (the -worker command-line argument).

Specified by:
setNumberOfWorkers in interface JobManager

waitForWorkers

public void waitForWorkers()
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException
This method is called by the main thread of the master process.
After it has set up its RMI registry, job manager and spawned its local worker(s), it calls setNumberOfWorkers() and then blocks in this method to wait for all workers (both local and remote) to register themselves at this job manager.
Only when all workers are ready, the distributed IDA* algorithm is ready to start its first iteration.

Specified by:
waitForWorkers in interface JobManager
java.lang.InterruptedException

instance

public static JobManager instance()
                           throws java.rmi.RemoteException
Use this factory method to obtain a reference to the central job manager.
Since there is only one central job manager in the entire distributed system, this method will return a remote reference when invoked in a remote process that is not the master.

When this method is invoked for the first time from the master process, it will create a local RMI registry and register the local job manager instance.
When invoked from a remote worker process for the first time, it will do a lookup in the RMI registry on the master process and return a reference to the remote object.

Returns:
a reference to the (either local or remote) job manager.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
java.rmi.RemoteException

put

public void put(Job job)
         throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Method to put a new job in the job manager's queue.
This job will at some point be returned by get().
In this implementation this method is only used by the manager thread that is in charge of creating new jobs and is never called by a remote process, but the implementation could be changed so that remote worker processes put partially expanded jobs back in the job manager's queue.

This method blocks if the queue is full until at least one job is removed by another thread.

Specified by:
put in interface JobManager
Parameters:
job - the job that is to be added to the manager's queue.
java.lang.InterruptedException

get

public Job get()
        throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
               OutOfWorkException
Description copied from interface: JobManager
Returns the first job (oldest) in the queue. If the queue is empty, this method will block until another thread adds a job.

Specified by:
get in interface JobManager
Returns:
the oldest job in the queue.
Throws:
OutOfWorkException - when the queue is empty and no more new jobs will be created.
java.lang.InterruptedException

addSolution

public void addSolution(Move move)
Description copied from interface: JobManager
Stores a solution to the puzzle. Remote workers invoke this method when an expanded job solved the game.

Specified by:
addSolution in interface JobManager
Parameters:
move - the Move that solved the game.

getSolutions

Specified by:
getSolutions in interface JobManager

idle

public void idle()
          throws java.lang.InterruptedException
When a worker process is out of jobs and the manager's get() method throws the OutOfWorkException to indicate no new jobs will come available, the worker invokes this method that acts as a barrier to synchronize all threads and detect termination of the algorithm.

When this method returns, the worker should again start calling the get() method as the algorithms starts a new iteration.

Specified by:
idle in interface JobManager
java.lang.InterruptedException

          throws java.lang.InterruptedException

join in interface JobManager
java.lang.InterruptedException

terminate

public void terminate()
Invoked by the master process' main thread before exiting the application after the puzzle has been solved.
This method tells all registered worker processes to kill themselves.

Specified by:
terminate in interface JobManager
